prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Detection trial for ASAS-SN1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Detection trial for the first quality ASAS-SN supernova suitable for ALMA observations

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request the use of four basebands with the largest bandwidth offered for continuum mode (7.5GHz effectively).

The SN will be a point source for ALMA, and we can observe them in any configuration (even at the highest resolution without missing flux). At the lowest resolutions, we will only trigger observations for SNe whose projected distance from the host galaxy nucleus is at least three times the resolution obtained with the current ALMA configuration.

Bright radio SNe have 5GHz luminosities > 1e27 erg/S/Hz. At early times, we expect the SNe will be absorbed at 5 GHz but largely unabsorbed at 100 GHz, such that 100 GHz emission will be equal to or brighter than the emission at 5 GHz. Assuming a mean distance of 25 Mpc and a typical spectral index of -0.7, we expect to detect a flux density of >0.16 mJy at 100GHz. To assess a 5*sigma detection, we request an rms of 32.7 mJy, which can be achieved in ~30 min.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Follow-up of ASAS-SN2016xx
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Follow-up of the first detected SN (three runs)

prj:VisitConstraint.prj:note: We will work with the ALMA staff to facilitate observations of potential radio SNe in the most timely manner possible and we will only trigger a follow- up when useful observations can be scheduled, to the benefit of both our program and the ALMA observatory. An initial trigger (SGs 1 to 5) will be done to secure our expected detection in a promptly manner (coordinating with ALMA staff). Once the detection is confirmed, we will trigger the follow-up (SGs 6 and 7) through a cadence spanning ~3 months. Given the diversity of radio SNe (e.g., fast evolving, long-lasting, etc.), we request some flexibility in how the follow-up time is used.

We will work with the ALMA staff to facilitate observations of potential radio SNe in the most timely manner possible and we will only trigger a follow- up when useful observations can be scheduled, to the benefit of both our program and the ALMA observatory. An initial trigger (SGs 1 to 5) will be done to secure our expected detection in a promptly manner (coordinating with ALMA staff). Once the detection is confirmed, we will trigger the follow-up (SGs 6 and 7) through a cadence spanning ~3 months. Given the diversity of radio SNe (e.g., fast evolving, long-lasting, etc.), we request some flexibility in how the follow-up time is used.

We will work with the ALMA staff to facilitate observations of potential radio SNe in the most timely manner possible and we will only trigger a follow- up when useful observations can be scheduled, to the benefit of both our program and the ALMA observatory. An initial trigger (SGs 1 to 5) will be done to secure our expected detection in a promptly manner (coordinating with ALMA staff). Once the detection is confirmed, we will trigger the follow-up (SGs 6 and 7) through a cadence spanning ~3 months. Given the diversity of radio SNe (e.g., fast evolving, long-lasting, etc.), we request some flexibility in how the follow-up time is used.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request the use of four basebands with the largest bandwidth offered for continuum mode (7.5GHz effectively).

The SN will be a point source for ALMA, and we can observe them in any configuration (even at the highest resolution without missing flux). At the lowest resolutions, we will only trigger observations for SNe whose projected distance from the host galaxy nucleus is at least three times the resolution obtained with the current ALMA configuration.

Bright radio SNe have 5GHz luminosities > 1e27 erg/S/Hz. At early times, we expect the SNe will be absorbed at 5 GHz but largely unabsorbed at 100 GHz, such that 100 GHz emission will be equal to or brighter than the emission at 5 GHz. Assuming a mean distance of 25 Mpc and a typical spectral index of -0.7, we expect to detect a flux density of >0.16 mJy at 100GHz. To assess a 5*sigma detection, we request an rms of 32.7 mJy, which can be achieved in ~30 min.

Follow-up observations on previously detected SNe (SGs 1 to 5), will be sought in a roughly logarithmic cadence in order to obtain a decent light-curve, but generally this would not pose strong scheduling constraints according to the maximum reaction time for cycle 3.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The All-Sky Automated Survey for Supernovae (ASAS-SN) is surveying the extraga- lactic sky with a high cadence (<2 days) and providing very young (a few days old), bright (mean V~16.4 mag), nearby (D<100 Mpc) SNe at a discovery rate of ~10 SN/month, which is a huge improvement compared to previous surveys. Here we propose a ToO pilot study in band 3 to observe five core-collapse SNe (CCSNe) from ASAS-SN. Robust early-time mm-continuum constraints can provide the information needed to break typical degeneracies and ambiguities in the multifrequency radio light curves as young CCSNe transition from the optically- thick to optically-thin regimes. This will yield an accurate assessment of the decreasing self-absorption, representing an important probe of the physical conditions of the circumstellar medium (B-field and free-electron distribution), and thus improving our understanding of the various CCSN sub-types, while providing insights on their progenitors. High-quality observations like we propose here can motivate decade-long monitoring campaigns to study the last several thousands of years of stellar evolution before explosion.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: A similar proposal was submitted in cycle 2. Code: 2013.1.00755.T / PI: Romero-Canizales / Title: Constraining the CSM around young supernovae with ALMA
